metadata.preacher: Likely Gardner C. Taylor (based on internal references to New Orleans/Mardi Gras and James Cayce)
metadata.sermon_start_end: I have glorified thee on earth: I have finished the work which thou gavest me to do. (John 17:4) There hangs in my office a painting which is a gift [...] To this you and I are summoned day by day.
metadata.liturgical_context: Not explicitly mentioned; likely a general Sunday service.
metadata.historical_context: Late 1960s/Early 1970s USA. References to 'anger and bitterness abroad in America', 'ugly racism', and 'terrifying streak of cruelty' point to the Civil Rights era and social unrest.
metadata.notes: The sermon bridges the gap between the high priestly prayer of Jesus and the social crisis of 20th-century America.

criterion_a1_imagery.analysis: The sermon excels in visual and sensory imagery, particularly through the opening anecdote of Sir Hans Heysen’s painting. This 'painting' metaphor serves as a powerful foil to the 'finished' work of Christ. The preacher uses concrete details—the skylight in a barn, the bold colors of a sunset, the 'death angel's wings'—to ground abstract theological concepts in physical reality. The transition from the literal painting to the metaphorical 'mask' of Mardi Gras is a brilliant use of local color to illustrate the deceptive nature of sin. It follows Paul Scott Wilson's 'show, don't tell' principle by describing the 'wicked leering laughs' of masks rather than just defining sin as 'deception.' The imagery of the 'cold rushing river of death' adds a visceral, almost cinematic quality to the crucifixion.
quotes: Standing in his studio underneath a skylight in what was once, I am sure, a barn...
Sin has always looked like something beautiful. It wears alluring garments and seems so light-hearted.
Jesus snatched the mask from the monster and showed the world that it is hideous and terrible, a crawling, loathsome thing.
strengths: Strong use of the 'unfinished painting' as a hook and recurring motif.
Sensory descriptions of the Mardi Gras masks create a vivid moral landscape.
Effective use of contrast between the 'fragrant flower' of life and the 'grim gallows' of the cross.
improvement_points: The transition from the 'monster' imagery to the political critique of America could be more visually bridged.
Some metaphors, like 'death angel's wings,' border on traditional homiletical tropes.
The 'symphony of life' is a slightly clichéd metaphor compared to the freshness of the Heysen painting.
criterion_a1_imagery.show_vs_tell_balance: Strongly weighted toward 'showing' through the painting and mask metaphors, though the final section moves more into 'telling' (exhortation).

criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.analysis: The language is elegant and precise, reflecting Marilyn Chandler McEntyre’s 'stewardship of language.' The preacher avoids heavy academic jargon, opting for a 'sober beauty' that is accessible yet profound. There is a clear rhythmic precision in the way human experience is described—the 'deep and satisfying drama of living' versus the 'darkness.' The word choice is deliberate, especially in the description of sin as 'sophisticated' and 'fashionable.' However, the latter half of the sermon becomes slightly more generalized when discussing 'events in our society,' losing some of the razor-sharp precision found in the opening narrative. The use of 'Buddy' in the anecdote adds a touch of authentic, precise human connection that grounds the theological reflection.
quotes: A look of excitement mixed with what I thought was a pensiveness and a wistfulness...
Sin—rebellion against God, human presumption, evil conniving—is exactly the opposite.
A sick suspicion about agencies in the life of the nation which should merit our esteem and respect...
strengths: Clear, economical definitions of complex theological states.
Avoidance of 'Canaanite' jargon in favor of evocative, plain English.
improvement_points: The phrase 'bright, particular promise' is slightly vague compared to the earlier descriptions.
The list of institutions (courts, churches, schools) feels a bit like a standard rhetorical list.
The conclusion relies on a long biblical quote rather than the preacher's own precise synthesis.
criterion_a2_carefulness_and_precision.jargon_analysis: Virtually no unexplained jargon; theological terms like 'sin' and 'Calvary' are contextualized through imagery.

criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.analysis: The sermon possesses a distinct oral cadence, characteristic of the best of the African American preaching tradition (though here in a more 'stately' register). There is a masterful use of parallelism and repetition ('We scarcely come... We hardly learn... We only begin...'). The sentence lengths are varied to create a sense of movement; short, punchy sentences ('What a word!') break up longer, more reflective periods. The rhythm mirrors the content: the 'tightening noose' of the narrative is reflected in the quickening pace of the description of Christ's trial. It is clearly 'ear language,' not 'paper language,' designed to be felt as much as heard.
quotes: The noose is tightening, the net is closing. Nothing seems to have come out right.
It is a liar fooling us. It is a murderer killing us. It is a troublemaker confusing our family life...
When they expected him to say something he kept silent. When they expected silence he spoke.
strengths: Excellent use of anaphora (repetition at the beginning of sentences) to build rhetorical momentum.
Natural 'flow' that moves between narrative, reflection, and proclamation.
The use of staccato sentences during the description of the crucifixion creates tension.
improvement_points: The transition to the final paragraph feels slightly abrupt in its rhythmic shift.
Some of the longer sentences in the middle section could benefit from more frequent pauses.
The ending is somewhat 'standard' in its liturgical rhythm compared to the unique rhythm of the introduction.
criterion_a3_musicality_and_rhythm.paper_language_diagnosis: Decidedly oral language; the rhythm is built for the pulpit, not the silent page.

domain_a_poetics_of_language.summary_language: The sermon demonstrates a high level of micro-aesthetic quality. The preacher uses a 'poetics of the ordinary'—a painting, a mask, a roommate's comment—to illuminate the 'extraordinary' work of Christ. The imagery is sensory and evocative, successfully 'showing' the deceptive nature of evil. The language is handled with stewardship and precision, avoiding jargon while maintaining a dignified, rhythmic cadence. It is a text that breathes, using rhetorical figures like parallelism and contrast to ensure the message is not just understood but felt.

criterion_b1_narrative_arc.analysis: The sermon follows a clear 'homiletical plot' as suggested by Eugene Lowry. It begins with an 'upsetting of equilibrium': the universal human experience of the 'unfinished task.' This creates a 'itch' that the sermon promises to scratch. The movement then shifts to the 'complication'—the apparent failure and brevity of Jesus' life. The 'turning point' is the redefinition of 'finished' not as 'longevity' but as 'unmasking.' The arc is strong, moving from the artist's studio to the cross, and finally to the streets of America. However, the energy slightly dissipates in the final section, where the 'solution' feels more like a standard call to action than the dramatic resolution the earlier tension demanded.
quotes: The symphony of life is almost always an unfinished one.
It did not look like it... he worked so briefly before they broke him on the grim gallows.
Jesus snatched the mask from the monster and showed the world that it is hideous and terrible...
strengths: Compelling 'hook' that connects a personal anecdote to a universal human existential crisis.
Effective 'reversal' where Christ's 'short' life is revealed as the only 'finished' one.
Maintains tension by delaying the explanation of what 'finished' actually means.
improvement_points: The connection between the 'unmasking of sin' and the 'unmasking of racism' could be more structurally integrated.
The conclusion feels a bit like a 'tacked-on' moral rather than a narrative climax.
The middle section on the trial of Jesus is slightly repetitive in its narrative movement.
criterion_b1_narrative_arc.plot_diagnosis: A dynamic journey from the frustration of human incompletion to the triumph of divine completion.

criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.analysis: This is a masterclass in Johan Cilliers’ 'reframing.' The preacher takes the high priestly prayer (John 17) and reframes it through the lens of an Australian landscape painting and the American Civil Rights crisis. The 'strangeness' of Jesus claiming completion while facing execution is honored and then used to 'reframe' the hearer's own sense of failure. The synthesis of the 'Mardi Gras' context with the theological concept of sin is organic and surprising. The sermon does not just 'apply' the text; it allows the text to unmask the contemporary 'ugly racism' of the 1960s/70s. It moves seamlessly between the 'then' of Galilee and the 'now' of a 'sick suspicion' in the nation.
quotes: Jesus corrects us about any impression we may have about his own brief, quickly passed life.
We in this land have posed as a most civilized and gentle people... events have forced us to show an ugly racism.
The mask must come off, and events in our society snatch it off.
strengths: The 'Mardi Gras' metaphor perfectly bridges the gap between cultural experience and theological truth.
The sermon addresses the social context (racism) without losing its grounding in the biblical text.
Surprising connection between the 'unfinished' painting and the 'finished' cross.
improvement_points: The transition to the American social crisis is quite sudden; a few more 'connective tissues' would help.
The 'reframing' of the nation's guilt could be even more deeply tied to the 'unmasking' at Calvary.
The final biblical quote (Isaiah 40) feels a bit disconnected from the 'unmasking' theme.
criterion_b2_integration_text_and_contex.reframing_present: Yes; it reframes 'success' and 'completion' from a matter of time/longevity to a matter of truth/revelation.

criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.analysis: While the sermon is an 'open work of art' in its use of metaphors (the painting allows for multiple interpretations of 'unfinished'), the theological conclusion is relatively 'closed.' The preacher moves toward a clear, almost moralistic 'summons' at the end. The 'unmasking' of sin is presented as a completed, objective fact, which leaves less room for the hearer's own struggle with the 'mask.' However, the inclusion of the 'unfinished' painting at the start provides an aesthetic 'openness' that lingers throughout the sermon. The hearer is invited to see their own 'unfinished business' in the light of Christ, but the path to 'walking in the light' is presented as a fairly straightforward duty.
quotes: I have never been able to finish it... a queer little sadness in the voice.
This is what Jesus did... and this is what you and I are called upon to do.
To this you and I are summoned day by day.
strengths: The opening anecdote respects the 'mystery' and 'wistfulness' of human effort.
The sermon acknowledges the 'ambivalence' of a life that looks like failure but is actually success.
The use of the 'unfinished' painting as a symbol for the human condition.
improvement_points: The ending is quite prescriptive ('we are called upon... we are summoned').
The 'unmasking' of racism is presented as an inevitable event rather than an open-ended struggle.
Could leave more room for the 'not yet'—the fact that while Christ finished his work, our world remains 'unfinished'.
criterion_b3_openness_vs_closedness.open_work_diagnosis: A mix; the imagery is polyvalent and open, but the structural movement is toward a monovalent moral summons.

domain_b_dramaturgy_of_structure.summary_structure: The macro-aesthetic quality is strong, characterized by a clear narrative arc and a sophisticated integration of text and context. The preacher successfully 'reframes' the biblical text by using contemporary cultural markers (painting, Mardi Gras, social unrest) to unlock the meaning of John 17:4. The structure moves from the existential 'itch' of incompletion to the theological 'scratch' of Christ’s finished work. While the conclusion leans toward a traditional, 'closed' moral exhortation, the overall journey is one of aesthetic depth and dramaturgical movement.

kitsch_diagnosis.analysis: The sermon largely avoids religious kitsch. It does not offer 'immediate comfort' or a 'happy ending' that ignores the 'pain of suffering.' Instead, it looks directly at the 'grim gallows' and the 'ugly racism' of the nation. The 'unfinished' painting is a sophisticated anti-kitsch symbol—it honors the sadness and failure of the artist rather than smoothing it over. The description of sin as a 'crawling, loathsome thing' is the opposite of the 'pre-chewed emotions' found in kitsch. The only slight risk of kitsch is in the 'symphony of life' metaphor, but the preacher quickly grounds it in the reality of broken family circles and death.
examples_of_kitsch: The 'symphony of life' metaphor is a bit of a homiletical cliché.
The 'fragrant flower cruelly and suddenly snapped off' borders on sentimentalism.
authentic_moments: The 'queer little sadness' in the artist's voice—an authentic observation of human limitation.
The blunt naming of 'ugly racism' and 'sick suspicion' in the American context.
kitsch_diagnosis.recommendation: Maintain the 'sober beauty' of the painting anecdote and avoid the more traditional 'flower' and 'symphony' metaphors to keep the aesthetic purely authentic.

space_for_grace_analysis.analysis: The sermon opens a significant 'space for grace' by redefining completion. It moves away from a 'works-based' view of a finished life (longevity, success) to a 'grace-based' view (truth, unmasking). By showing that Christ 'finished' his work in the midst of apparent failure, it creates space for the hearer to find grace in their own 'unfinished' lives. However, the space is slightly constricted at the end by the shift to 'summons' and 'duty.' The 'mystery' of the unfinished painting is somewhat 'explained away' by the theological points that follow, but the central image of the cross as an 'unmasking' remains a powerful opening for the Holy.
space_for_grace_analysis.tension_sustained: The tension between 'brief life' and 'finished work' is well-sustained until the middle of the sermon.
space_for_grace_analysis.mystery_respected: The mystery of the artist's inability to finish the painting is respected and used as a gateway to the divine.
space_for_grace_analysis.moralization_vs_grace: Grace prevails in the redefinition of Christ's work, but moralization takes over in the final two paragraphs.
space_for_grace_analysis.recommendation: Allow the 'unmasking' to be a gift of the Spirit that the hearer experiences, rather than just a 'task' they are summoned to perform.

overall_aesthetics.summary: This sermon is an aesthetically robust example of 'reframing' homiletics. Its primary strength lies in its 'micro-aesthetics'—the use of vivid, sensory imagery and a rhythmic, oral prose that does justice to the gravity of the subject. The preacher avoids the 'kitsch' of easy answers by starting with the 'wistfulness' of an unfinished painting and ending with the 'ugly' reality of social sin. The 'macro-aesthetics' are equally strong, with a narrative arc that moves from a personal anecdote to a universal existential crisis, then to a Christological resolution, and finally to a social critique. While the ending is somewhat more 'closed' and moralistic than the 'open work of art' suggested by the beginning, the sermon successfully creates a 'space for grace' by showing that God's 'finished work' happens precisely where human efforts seem most 'unfinished.' It is a 'sober-Reformed' aesthetic that uses beauty not for its own sake, but as a transparent medium for the truth of the Gospel.
strengths_top_3: The 'unfinished painting' as a profound and original aesthetic hook.
The 'Mardi Gras mask' as a vivid, culturally grounded metaphor for the nature of sin.
The rhythmic, oral quality of the prose which creates a palpable sense of movement and tension.
improvement_points_top_3: The transition to the social/political application could be more organically woven into the 'unmasking' imagery.
The conclusion could be more 'open,' leaving the hearer in the mystery of grace rather than a list of duties.
Replacing clichéd metaphors (flowers, symphonies) with more of the 'sober' imagery found in the painting anecdote.
overall_aesthetics.comparison_with_specialists: Fits Johan Cilliers (reframing, anti-kitsch) and Paul Scott Wilson (imagery, Four Pages structure).
overall_aesthetics.audience_analysis: Aesthetically appeals to hearers who value narrative depth, social relevance, and a dignified, rhythmic delivery. It speaks to the 'wistful' intellectual and the socially conscious believer.
recommendations_for_next_sermon: Experiment with an 'open ending' that leaves the tension of the 'unfinished' with the hearer.
Use the 'show, don't tell' principle even in the social application—describe a scene of 'racism unmasked' rather than just naming it.
Deepen the 'musicality' by using more silence and varied pacing in the delivery (implied in the text).
overall_aesthetics.conclusion: An aesthetically 'strong' (7.3) sermon that demonstrates how a preacher can be a 'steward of language' and an 'artist of the soul.' By avoiding religious kitsch and embracing the 'sober beauty' of human limitation, the sermon opens a space where the 'finished work' of Christ can be seen in a new, transformative light. It is a model of how to integrate personal anecdote, biblical exegesis, and social context into a single, coherent aesthetic movement.
